multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following best describes the matrix U in the context of hyperspectral imaging?
choices: The hyperspectral image itself, with each entry representing reflectance at a specific wavelength.
A matrix representing the abundances of each material in each pixel of the image.
A matrix containing the spectral signatures of the endmembers present in the image.
A weighting matrix used to combine different spectral channels for visualization.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the matrix V represent in the context of hyperspectral imaging?
choices: The noise present in the hyperspectral image.
The different wavelengths measured by the hyperspectral imager.
The abundances of each endmember in each pixel of the image.
The spatial correlation between neighboring pixels in the image.

multiple_choice_question.text: What geometric problem is illustrated in Figure 3 in relation to exact NMF?
choices: Finding the minimum enclosing sphere of a set of points.
Determining the convex hull of a set of points in two dimensions.
Identifying the minimum-volume ellipsoid enclosing a polytope.
Finding a nested polytope with a specific number of vertices between two given polytopes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the objective function in Formula (3) aim to achieve?
choices: Minimize the difference between the original matrix M and its low-rank approximation UV.
Maximize the sparsity of the factor matrices U and V.
Enforce the sum-to-one constraint on the columns of V.
Find a factorization where both U and V have orthogonal columns.
